ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A survey of quantum physics, from its origins to modern topics.

I gained a lot of scientific understanding and reasoning skills. Not only did we learn interesting scientific concepts, but we learned how to think them through and understand their conceptual framework and background, along with how they all relate to each other.
Very good high -level overview of topics in cosmology, classical and quantum mechanics.
This was a great survey and introductory course to topics in general relativity, special relativity, and quantum mechanics.
I developed a general understanding of the history of Quantum Physics as well as a broad survey of topics in quantum physics. I learned how to read scientific articles and present information.
Quantum physics
This course introduced me to topics relevant to modern quantum physics in a manner easily understood by a non STEM major.

Before taking this course, I thought quantum physics was some sort of enigma that I could never understand but it ended up just being good old physics but weird because you get into this whole idea of discarding classical physics and things get a little wonky but yeah. A really great skill I learned in this class is calculating spins of quarks, interpreting Schrodinger's wave function equation, the Heisenberg principle, subcategories of matter, antimatter, dark matter, etc. More importantly, though, I learned how to distinguish classical physics theories from quantum mechanics which involved reconfiguring my brain (which has always studied classical physics) to understand quantum mechanics. But it was fun.
Some basic knowledge of major developments or concepts in quantum physics; Big Bang, black holes, quantum entanglement, relativity.
An introductory foundation into quantum physics (Big Bang, quantum mechanics, light, General and Special Relativity, quantum computing, etc)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Really interesting readings and assignments that actually help you learn!

Strengths - great professor, who does a great job answering questions; readings give good background to the topics in class
Weaknesses - only meet once a week
Slides were a bit disorganized

Strengths: the course material was interesting and the professor really listened to our suggestions/feedback 

Weaknesses: The professor and her lectures were sometimes a bit boring as we had already covered that content during the readings. The weekly meetings were more like lectures rather than seminars and it would be nice to interact with the other students in that class.

Strengths were the professor and the lectures. Weakness is that it lacked engagement in class. The seminar-style for over 2 hours is hard to get through if you're just listening to the professor speak, no matter how well she does it or how interesting the topic is.
Great course - more opportunities for feedback wouldve been nice

Strengths- Content complex enough to not be boring, but not such that it wasn't able to be followed.
Weaknesses- The seminar time slot is essentially used for a lecture, Prof Caines was very receptive to student questions, but there wasn't much or any student discussion. Might be better off as a biweekly 1 hour 15min lecture. Midterm harder than overall psets and course content.
I think the strengths are the way Professor Caines teaches such complex material in a really digestible way that it's not too overwhelming. A weakness was the 5am Tuesday deadlines for psets.

I would not take this course. Lectures are very long and not well explained. Course is quite boring even though the content should be very interesting. Also, since Its run as a leminar you have to go to class.

strengths: the class is very well organized for students with little to no quantum background and was easy to follow along (especially with reading assignments due the morning before class allowing students to be exposed to the material beforehand) 

weakness: with the class only meeting once a week with ~2 hour lectures, I do wish there were more in-class activities/discussions besides just the lecture in order to interact with my classmates and the material more

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! A perfect science class for non-STEM majors. If you're looking to fulfill your science distributional requirement, this is a class that won't overwhelm you with work and you'll still learn a lot.
I would. This class was not only highly interesting, but at the perfect point of being challenging but accessible to almost all students
Yes, just make sure you keep up with the material and take advantage of Prof Caines' generosity with her time in office hours!
Yes - if you love topics in modern physics but want a better understanding of it, this course is for you!
Yes. It is a great way of earning a science credit while learning something cool. You can also tell you're friends and family that you are taking quantum physics.
Yes, a relatively interesting and low-workload science credit.
This is the best science credit at Yale. Do not hesitate to take this.
Yes- good and interesring course to fulfill a science credit

No. You will not understand any of the material, because they don't intend for you to understand it. You will get hand wavy descriptions of vague physics things. The seminar is a 2 hour lecture which is very boring and even if you want to listen you won't be able to because it's not taught such that you could actually understand anything

Yes I would 100% especially if you want to have conversational knowledge about quantum mechanics and do a cool final presentation. Oo also you get to learn about quarks which are annoying to wrap your head around but cool (eventually). And this class is also fun if you watch Big Bang theory with Sheldon or a fan of MCU.
Definitely not. Learned almost nothing and the lectures were very boring. Assigned reading were not great either - Wikipedia often did a better (and more detailed!?!) job if explaining.

I would highly recommend this course to any student interested in getting a crash course into quantum physics. Especially as a non-STEM person, this course was a great science credit and was also pretty easy to follow along as lectures were well organized and the reading assignments were also helpful in taking in material
